news_summary: Today's space news highlights advancements in space food benefiting everyday life, community engagement through educational events at NASA, upcoming innovation challenges, and new discoveries about ghost particles influencing star collapse.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité spatiale d'aujourd'hui met en lumière les avancées dans le domaine de l'alimentation spatiale au service de la vie quotidienne, l'engagement de la communauté par le biais d'événements éducatifs à la NASA, les prochains défis en matière d'innovation et les nouvelles découvertes sur les particules fantômes qui influencent l'effondrement des étoiles.
news_summary_es: Las noticias espaciales de hoy destacan los avances en alimentos espaciales que benefician la vida cotidiana, el compromiso de la comunidad a través de eventos educativos en la NASA, los próximos retos de innovación y los nuevos descubrimientos sobre partículas fantasma que influyen en el colapso estelar.

articles.title: Why space foods aren’t just for space
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02337-9Space agencies looking to set up long-term bases on the Moon need sustainable ways to feed astronauts. The approaches they are testing could also help to tackle challenges on Earth.
articles.content:
When it comes to food, the difficulties faced by astronauts, older people and those affected by disaster are more similar than you might think.

Space agencies worldwide are rolling out plans to build bases on the Moon. One challenge is how to nourish astronauts by growing fresh food in the extreme conditions on the lunar surface — in soils with few nutrients and where there is scarce water and no air. It’s too expensive to send supplies from Earth regularly, and long-term storage is difficult because foods decay.

Without healthy food, astronauts on long missions might face malnutrition, just like people on Earth do. They lose bone and muscle mass when working in low gravity1, mirroring changes that occur naturally during ageing. Food systems for any future missions need to be sustainable and resilient — as does food production on Earth in the face of climate change.

Here, we highlight four areas of common ground between space and Earth-bound nutrition research programmes that need exploring.

Maintaining food supplies

In the aftermath of disasters, affected people need access to food. With water, electricity and gas supplies often cut off, there are parallels with remote operations in space. In Japan, earthquakes, tsunamis, typhoons and floods occur frequently, and the country has been learning from these parallels for the past decade.

How to keep astronauts healthy in deep space

As in space, disaster food supplies for emergencies must be stable when stored at room temperature in the absence of power and refrigeration2. They must come in durable packaging that protects against damage and contamination. Meals must require minimal preparation and be easy for anyone to eat with limited equipment. And they must be prepared and packed in hygienic environments to prevent foodborne illnesses. In Japan, pre-cooked and dried rice, dried noodles, fermented products such as miso, sweets and jelly drinks, and fish or meat stored in cans or sterile plastic pouches are used in both disaster settings and space.

The Tōhoku earthquake in Japan in 2011 led to changes in how disaster foods are managed. Emergency shelters saw food-supply disruptions as well as problems with limited dietary diversity and hygiene3,4. Recognizing that many of the stringent space-food standards set by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) were applicable to disaster contexts, the Japan Disaster Food Society launched its Disaster Food Certification System in 2015.

In 2022, the society introduced a streamlined cross-certification process, allowing JAXA-approved Japanese space foods to be certified as disaster food. This reduces duplicate product development and, in large-scale emergencies, means that foods earmarked for space missions can be diverted to humanitarian use (although these are not stored in large amounts).

Japan has developed about 53 space foods through JAXA’s programme — some have been stockpiled for disaster preparedness by local governments and deployed in emergency situations, including in earthquake-affected regions.

People received emergency rations after an earthquake hit Wajima City in Japan in 2024.Credit: Yomiuri Shimbun/AP Images/Alamy

Now, one of us (N.T.-K.) is working with experts to develop an international standard for emergency and disaster foods. This could simplify food-aid coordination between governments and non-governmental organizations by standardizing stockpiling conditions, hygiene protocols and food labelling. Shared protocols could also help countries to adopt advanced food-production and preservation technologies originally developed for space for their own emergency and disaster food supplies.

The next step is to build consensus among food-safety authorities, humanitarian organizations and space agencies. Implementation of pilot projects in disaster-prone regions of Asia is under consideration. Challenges include aligning diverse national regulations, encouraging private-sector participation in dual-use product development and demonstrating cost-effectiveness in resource-limited settings.

Optimizing nutrition

Japan’s government recommends4 that food provided to emergency shelters should contain five elements: energy, protein and vitamins B 1 , B 2 and C. Together, these factors prevent deficiency-related diseases such as beriberi, ariboflavinosis and scurvy, and help to sustain basic physiological functions.

As part of JAXA’s Lunar Food System Working Group 2023–25, one of us (N.T.-K.) is evaluating whether a set of eight staple crops — rice, potatoes, sweet potatoes, soya beans, tomatoes, cucumbers, lettuce and strawberries — can provide these five elements and other crucial nutrients. These crops are rich in carbohydrates, dietary fibre and certain vitamins.

How to chart a moral future for space exploration

The working group is using nutritional modelling, simulations of human dietary intake and cultivation studies under controlled environmental conditions to assess how much of astronauts’ daily nutritional requirements could be met using just these eight crops, and to identify any nutritional gaps that would require supplements.

Antioxidant compounds have anti-inflammatory and other effects that might help to prevent muscle deconditioning caused by microgravity in space and in people who are confined to bed rest on Earth because of illness or age. The French, German and Canadian space agencies are examining whether a cocktail of antioxidant supplements — polyphenols, vitamin E, selenium and omega-3 fatty acids — could prevent muscle deconditioning. Although there is no firm evidence yet5, the agencies are planning to assess these compounds’ benefits in space.

Supplements generated using soya might also help to prevent the wasting of astronauts’ muscles and bones. One of us (T.N.), together with colleagues, has conducted experiments in space using rats6 and cells grown in culture7 to reveal that muscle atrophy comes about when microgravity induces oxidative stress in muscle tissues. The process activates enzymes that alter cell signalling such that protein synthesis ceases and degradation increases. The same changes were subsequently shown to occur in adults under bed-rest conditions, and a clinical trial found that oral intake of soya proteins, especially Cblin-like peptides — which prevent this protein-degradation pathway from being activated — increases the quadricep strength of people on bed-rest8.

We are now testing whether similar Cblin peptides can also help astronauts, through experiments in cultured muscle cells aboard the International Space Station (ISS).

Specialists who can take a high-level view of micronutrient function, delivery methods and physiological needs under stress could vastly improve our ability to build resilience into future food systems — on Earth and beyond.

Alternative protein sources

Sustainable sources of alternative protein are urgently needed to avoid widespread food insecurity and malnutrition on Earth. A 2019 survey of Japanese citizens found that, on average, more than 50% of a person’s protein intake was derived from animal-based sources such as meat, dairy and fish (see go.nature.com/44xwmyn). But with the global population projected to reach nine billion by 2050, there is concern that current protein sources will be insufficient to meet global nutritional needs9.

Alternative protein sources are a focus of research for space agencies, too. Conventional animal agriculture requires large amounts of water, land and feedstock — resources that are unavailable in space. Protein-production systems involving plants, cultured cells or insects are more viable options.

Soya protein is of interest to JAXA, because of its high yield, relatively complete amino-acid profile and long shelf life, and because it is widely consumed in Japan. One of us (T.N.) has been involved in developing a compact soya-bean cultivation system. It uses programmable LED lighting and supplies nutrients through a mist infused with rhizobia — bacteria that convert inert nitrogen into forms that plants can use to grow10. Next, we hope to test its applicability aboard the ISS.

Japanese astronaut Kimiya Yui enjoys a taste of home while in space: ramen noodles with soy sauce.Credit: JAXA/NASA

Meat produced from animal cells grown in the laboratory could give astronauts some of the nutrients that soya protein lacks — particularly branched-chain amino acids, which muscles need to generate energy during exercise. Cultured meat can be produced under sterile conditions, reducing the risk of foodborne illness11. However, this technology is in its infancy. Cells need to be coaxed to keep proliferating so that they form large, structured tissue pieces. Getting oxygen to the core of thick cultures is tricky. The liquids in which the cells need to be grown are expensive to produce and transport. And there isn’t a good way to generate cultures with meat-like textures, which are important for psychological satisfaction.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights innovative approaches to sustainable food production for long-term space missions, which also have potential benefits for addressing food challenges on Earth. This represents scientific progress and technology solving real problems, offering hope for both space exploration and terrestrial sustainability.
articles.personality_title: How space foods are helping us solve Earth's food challenges
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Space agencies are planning to build long-term bases on the Moon. One big challenge is feeding astronauts in a place where soil lacks nutrients, water is scarce, and there is no air. Sending food from Earth often is too costly, and storing it for a long time is tricky.

**What happened**
Scientists are developing new ways to grow fresh food on the Moon using limited resources. These methods focus on creating sustainable food systems that can work in tough environments with little water and poor soil.

**Impact**
These space-tested food-growing techniques are also useful for Earth. They can help feed older adults, people affected by disasters, and communities facing harsh growing conditions, showing how space science can improve life here at home.

**What's next step**
Researchers will continue refining these food-growing methods, aiming to make them more efficient and adaptable. The goal is to support both space missions and help solve food security problems on Earth.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Innovations in space food are not only fueling astronauts but also offering smart solutions to feed people in difficult Earth environments.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment les aliments spatiaux aident à résoudre les défis alimentaires sur Terre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les agences spatiales prévoient de construire des bases à long terme sur la Lune. Un grand défi est de nourrir les astronautes dans un endroit où le sol manque de nutriments, l'eau est rare et il n'y a pas d'air. Envoyer de la nourriture depuis la Terre est trop coûteux et la conservation à long terme est difficile.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des scientifiques développent de nouvelles façons de cultiver des aliments frais sur la Lune avec peu de ressources. Ces méthodes visent à créer des systèmes alimentaires durables capables de fonctionner dans des environnements difficiles avec peu d'eau et un sol pauvre.

**Impact**
Ces techniques de culture testées dans l’espace sont aussi utiles sur Terre. Elles peuvent aider à nourrir les personnes âgées, les victimes de catastrophes, et les communautés vivant dans des conditions difficiles, montrant comment la science spatiale peut améliorer la vie ici-bas.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs continueront à améliorer ces méthodes de culture pour les rendre plus efficaces et adaptables. L’objectif est de soutenir à la fois les missions spatiales et de résoudre les problèmes alimentaires sur Terre.

**En une phrase**
Les innovations alimentaires spatiales nourrissent non seulement les astronautes, mais offrent aussi des solutions intelligentes pour alimenter les populations dans des environnements difficiles sur Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo los alimentos espaciales están ayudando a resolver los desafíos alimentarios en la Tierra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Las agencias espaciales planean construir bases a largo plazo en la Luna. Un gran desafío es alimentar a los astronautas en un lugar donde el suelo tiene pocos nutrientes, el agua es escasa y no hay aire. Enviar comida desde la Tierra es muy costoso y el almacenamiento a largo plazo es complicado.

**Qué pasó**
Los científicos están desarrollando nuevas formas de cultivar alimentos frescos en la Luna usando pocos recursos. Estos métodos se centran en crear sistemas de alimentos sostenibles que funcionen en ambientes difíciles con poca agua y suelo pobre.

**Impacto**
Estas técnicas de cultivo probadas en el espacio también son útiles en la Tierra. Pueden ayudar a alimentar a personas mayores, afectados por desastres y comunidades en condiciones difíciles, mostrando cómo la ciencia espacial puede mejorar la vida aquí.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores seguirán perfeccionando estos métodos de cultivo para hacerlos más eficientes y adaptables. El objetivo es apoyar tanto misiones espaciales como resolver problemas de seguridad alimentaria en la Tierra.

**Una frase clave**
Las innovaciones en alimentos espaciales no solo alimentan a los astronautas, sino que también ofrecen soluciones inteligentes para alimentar a personas en entornos difíciles en la Tierra.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm drawing of a thriving lunar greenhouse glowing gently under a starry sky, with vibrant crops like soybeans, tomatoes, and strawberries growing in neat rows beside packaged emergency rations styled as sealed pouches and cans, all connected by softly glowing roots symbolizing nourishment linking space and Earth, set against a calm backdrop blending the Moon’s surface with a peaceful Japanese coastal village recovering from disaster.

articles.title: Join Second Lady Usha Vance as She Reads to Children at NASA Johnson
articles.summary: As part of her Summer Reading Challenge, Second Lady Usha Vance will host an event for children in grades K-8 on Monday, Aug. 4, at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. Media are invited. NASA astronaut Suni Williams will join Ms. Vance to read a space-related book to children and participate in other space-related activities. […]
articles.content:
As part of her Summer Reading Challenge, Second Lady Usha Vance will host an event for children in grades K-8 on Monday, Aug. 4, at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. Credit: White House

As part of her Summer Reading Challenge, Second Lady Usha Vance will host an event for children in grades K-8 on Monday, Aug. 4, at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. Media are invited.

NASA astronaut Suni Williams will join Ms. Vance to read a space-related book to children and participate in other space-related activities.

Live coverage of the reading will stream about 2:45 p.m. EDT on NASA+. Learn how to watch NASA content through a variety of platforms, including social media.

U.S. media interested in participating in this event must RSVP to NASA Press Secretary Bethany Stevens at: bethany.c.stevens@nasa.gov, as well as Office of the Second Lady Communications Director Nicole Reeves at: nicole.e.reeves@ovp.eop.gov. Requests must be made no later than 1 p.m. EDT on Thursday, July 31. Confirmed media will receive additional details from NASA. The agency’s media accreditation policy is online.

Through her reading challenge, the Second Lady is encouraging youth to seek adventure, imagination, and discovery between the pages of a book. Students interested in participating in the challenge must read 12 books by Friday, Sept. 5. Additional details, including where to download a reading log, and how to submit it to the White House, are available online.

As part of NASA’s Artemis campaign, the agency will send astronauts to the Moon to prepare for future human exploration of Mars, inspiring Golden Age explorers, and ensuring the United States continues to lead in space exploration and discovery.

Learn more about NASA missions online at:

https://www.nasa.gov

-end-

Bethany Stevens / Cheryl Warner

Headquarters, Washington

202-358-1600

bethany.c.stevens@nasa.gov / cheryl.m.warner@nasa.gov
articles.reasoning: The story highlights an educational and community event where the Second Lady and an astronaut engage children in reading and space-related activities, promoting literacy and interest in science.
articles.personality_title: Second Lady Usha Vance inspires kids with storytime at NASA
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Summer is a perfect time for kids to explore new worlds through books. To encourage this, Second Lady Usha Vance launched a Summer Reading Challenge aimed at children in kindergarten through eighth grade, blending fun with learning.

**What happened**
On August 4, at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston, Ms. Vance hosted a special event where she and astronaut Suni Williams read a space-themed book to children. The event included space-related activities, making reading an exciting adventure linked to real-world science.

**Impact**
This event helped spark kids’ curiosity about space and science, while encouraging reading. Having a prominent leader and an astronaut read together showed children that learning can be both fun and important, helping build enthusiasm for education and STEM subjects.

**What's next step**
The Summer Reading Challenge continues, aiming to reach more children with similar events and activities. By combining storytelling with inspiring role models, the program hopes to keep kids excited about reading and science all summer long.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Second Lady Usha Vance’s NASA storytime brilliantly connects reading with space exploration, inspiring young minds to dream big and learn more.
articles.personality_title_fr: La seconde dame Usha Vance inspire les enfants avec une séance de lecture à la NASA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
L’été est le moment idéal pour les enfants d’explorer de nouveaux mondes à travers les livres. Pour encourager cela, la seconde dame Usha Vance a lancé un défi de lecture d’été destiné aux enfants de la maternelle à la huitième année, mêlant plaisir et apprentissage.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Le 4 août, au Centre spatial Johnson de la NASA à Houston, Mme Vance a organisé un événement spécial où elle et l’astronaute Suni Williams ont lu un livre sur le thème de l’espace aux enfants. L’événement comprenait des activités liées à l’espace, rendant la lecture une aventure passionnante liée à la science réelle.

**Impact**
Cet événement a aidé à éveiller la curiosité des enfants pour l’espace et la science, tout en encourageant la lecture. Voir une leader importante et une astronaute lire ensemble a montré aux enfants que l’apprentissage peut être à la fois amusant et important, aidant à développer l'enthousiasme pour l’éducation et les matières STEM.

**Prochaine étape**
Le défi de lecture d’été continue, visant à toucher davantage d’enfants avec des événements et activités similaires. En combinant narration et modèles inspirants, le programme espère garder les enfants enthousiastes pour la lecture et la science tout l’été.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
La séance de lecture à la NASA animée par la seconde dame Usha Vance relie brillamment la lecture à l’exploration spatiale, inspirant les jeunes esprits à rêver grand et à apprendre davantage.
articles.personality_title_es: La segunda dama Usha Vance inspira a los niños con lectura en la NASA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El verano es un momento perfecto para que los niños exploren nuevos mundos a través de los libros. Para fomentar esto, la segunda dama Usha Vance lanzó un Desafío de Lectura de Verano dirigido a niños desde jardín de infantes hasta octavo grado, combinando diversión y aprendizaje.

**Qué pasó**
El 4 de agosto, en el Centro Espacial Johnson de la NASA en Houston, la Sra. Vance organizó un evento especial donde ella y la astronauta Suni Williams leyeron un libro sobre el espacio a los niños. El evento incluyó actividades relacionadas con el espacio, haciendo que la lectura fuera una aventura emocionante vinculada a la ciencia real.

**Impacto**
Este evento ayudó a despertar la curiosidad de los niños por el espacio y la ciencia, mientras fomentaba la lectura. Ver a una líder importante y a una astronauta leer juntas mostró a los niños que aprender puede ser divertido e importante, ayudando a crear entusiasmo por la educación y las materias STEM.

**Próximo paso**
El Desafío de Lectura de Verano continúa, con el objetivo de alcanzar a más niños con eventos y actividades similares. Al combinar la narración con modelos a seguir inspiradores, el programa espera mantener a los niños entusiasmados con la lectura y la ciencia durante todo el verano.

**Mensaje en una frase**
La lectura en la NASA con la segunda dama Usha Vance conecta brillantemente la lectura con la exploración espacial, inspirando a las mentes jóvenes a soñar en grande y aprender más.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of an open storybook floating above a model of the NASA Johnson Space Center, with playful silhouettes of children gathered around, and a graceful astronaut figure made of stardust gently pointing toward a glowing crescent moon and Mars in the background, all rendered in soft, natural hues.

articles.title: 2025 NASA Space Apps Challenge
articles.summary: Join the 2025 NASA International Space Apps Challenge: Learn, Launch, Lead On October 4–5, 2025, NASA—along with 14 international space agency partners—invites scientists, engineers, coders, designers, storytellers, and space enthusiasts of all kinds to take part in the 2025 NASA International Space Apps Challenge. This two-day global hackathon brings together diverse teams to tackle real-world […]
articles.content:
Join the 2025 NASA International Space Apps Challenge: Learn, Launch, Lead

On October 4–5, 2025, NASA—along with 14 international space agency partners—invites scientists, engineers, coders, designers, storytellers, and space enthusiasts of all kinds to take part in the 2025 NASA International Space Apps Challenge. This two-day global hackathon brings together diverse teams to tackle real-world problems using NASA’s open data, alongside space-based data from agencies around the world.

This year’s theme, Learn, Launch, Lead, encourages participants to:

Learn new skills and deepen their understanding of STEM,

new skills and deepen their understanding of STEM, Launch bold ideas by transforming open data into actionable solutions, and

bold ideas by transforming open data into actionable solutions, and Lead communities in pioneering innovation and discovery.

Participants will collaborate to develop creative, open-source projects that address Earth and space-related challenges. Whether you're a seasoned developer, an aspiring student, or a creative thinker, there's a place for you in this global movement.

Together, we’ll use the power of open data and global collaboration to solve some of the world’s toughest challenges—on Earth and beyond.

Learn more and register now!
articles.reasoning: The article promotes a global collaborative event hosted by NASA and international partners that encourages learning, innovation, and teamwork to solve real-world problems using space-related technology. This fosters education, cooperation, and technological progress, which are positive and inspiring themes.
articles.personality_title: Join the 2025 NASA Space Apps Challenge: A global team event to solve real-world problems
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
NASA, along with 14 international space agencies, is hosting the 2025 International Space Apps Challenge on October 4–5. This event is a global hackathon where people from all backgrounds like scientists, coders, designers, and storytellers come together.

**What happened**
For two days, participants will form diverse teams to work on real-world challenges using open data from NASA and other space agencies. This collaboration allows teams to use space-related information to create innovative solutions.

**Impact**
The challenge encourages learning, teamwork, and creativity in technology. It promotes global cooperation and inspires people to use space data to tackle important problems on Earth.

**What's next step**
Interested individuals can register to join the event and start preparing by exploring NASA’s open data. Teams will compete, share ideas, and develop their projects during the challenge days.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The 2025 NASA Space Apps Challenge is a worldwide opportunity to learn, collaborate, and innovate using space science to improve our world.
articles.personality_title_fr: Participez au défi Space Apps 2025 de la NASA : un événement mondial pour résoudre des problèmes réels
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La NASA, avec 14 agences spatiales internationales, organise le défi International Space Apps 2025 les 4 et 5 octobre. Cet événement est un hackathon mondial où des personnes de tous horizons comme des scientifiques, codeurs, designers et conteurs se réunissent.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Pendant deux jours, les participants formeront des équipes diverses pour travailler sur des défis réels en utilisant les données ouvertes de la NASA et d'autres agences spatiales. Cette collaboration permet d'utiliser les informations liées à l'espace pour créer des solutions innovantes.

**Impact**
Le défi encourage l'apprentissage, le travail d'équipe et la créativité en technologie. Il favorise la coopération mondiale et inspire les gens à utiliser les données spatiales pour résoudre des problèmes importants sur Terre.

**Prochaine étape**
Les personnes intéressées peuvent s'inscrire pour rejoindre l'événement et commencer à se préparer en explorant les données ouvertes de la NASA. Les équipes concourront, partageront des idées et développeront leurs projets pendant les jours du défi.

**En une phrase**
Le défi Space Apps 2025 de la NASA est une occasion mondiale d'apprendre, collaborer et innover grâce à la science spatiale pour améliorer notre monde.
articles.personality_title_es: Únete al Desafío Space Apps 2025 de la NASA: un evento global para resolver problemas reales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La NASA, junto con 14 agencias espaciales internacionales, organiza el Desafío Internacional Space Apps 2025 los días 4 y 5 de octubre. Este evento es un hackatón global que reúne a personas de todos los ámbitos como científicos, programadores, diseñadores y narradores.

**Qué pasó**
Durante dos días, los participantes formarán equipos diversos para trabajar en desafíos del mundo real usando datos abiertos de la NASA y otras agencias espaciales. Esta colaboración permite usar información espacial para crear soluciones innovadoras.

**Impacto**
El desafío fomenta el aprendizaje, el trabajo en equipo y la creatividad en tecnología. Promueve la cooperación global e inspira a las personas a usar datos espaciales para enfrentar problemas importantes en la Tierra.

**Próximo paso**
Las personas interesadas pueden registrarse para unirse al evento y comenzar a prepararse explorando los datos abiertos de la NASA. Los equipos competirán, compartirán ideas y desarrollarán sus proyectos durante los días del desafío.

**Una frase clave**
El Desafío Space Apps 2025 de la NASA es una oportunidad mundial para aprender, colaborar e innovar usando la ciencia espacial para mejorar nuestro mundo.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of interconnected glowing data streams flowing from Earth and various international space agencies' satellites into an imaginative, abstract globe, surrounded by symbolic icons of rockets launching upward and stylized open books and gears representing learning and innovation, all rendered in soft, natural tones with a harmonious, collaborative atmosphere.

articles.title: Ghost particles may secretly decide the fate of collapsing stars
articles.summary: Neutrinos, ghostly particles barely interacting with matter, may secretly be reshaping the fates of massive stars. New research suggests that as stars collapse, they form natural "neutrino colliders," allowing scientists to probe these elusive particles in ways never possible on Earth. If neutrinos do interact through yet-undiscovered forces, they could cause stars to collapse into black holes instead of neutron stars, reshaping how we understand cosmic evolution.
articles.content:
Neutrinos are cosmic tricksters, paradoxically hardly there but lethal to stars significantly more massive than the sun. These elementary particles come in three known "flavors": electron, muon and tau. Whatever the flavor, neutrinos are notoriously slippery, and much about their properties remains mysterious. It is almost impossible to collide neutrinos with each other in the lab, so it is not known if neutrinos interact with each other according to the standard model of particle physics, or if there are much-speculated "secret" interactions only among neutrinos.

Now a team of researchers from the Network for Neutrinos, Nuclear Astrophysics, and Symmetries (N3AS), including several from UC San Diego, have shown, through theoretical calculations, how collapsing massive stars can act as a "neutrino collider." Neutrinos steal thermal energy from these stars, forcing them to contract and causing their electrons to move near light speed. This drives the stars to instability and collapse

Eventually the collapsing star's density becomes so high that the neutrinos are trapped and collide with each other. With purely standard model interactions, the neutrinos will be mostly electron flavor, the matter will be relatively "cold," and the collapse will likely leave a neutron star remnant. However, secret interactions that change neutrino flavor radically alter this scenario, producing neutrinos of all flavors and leading to a mostly neutron "hot" core that may lead to a black hole remnant.

Fermi National Accelerator Lab's upcoming Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE) might be able to test these ideas, as might future observations of the neutrinos or gravitational waves from collapsing stars.

The study, published June 18, 2025 in Physical Review Letters, was led by UC San Diego researchers Anna M. Suliga, Julien Froustey, Lukáš Gráf, Kyle Kehrer and George Fuller, as well as collaborators from other institutions. Their research was funded, in part, by the National Science Foundation (PHY-2209578 and PHY-2020275), the Department of Energy (DE-AC02-07CHI11359), and the Heising-Simons Foundation (2017-228).
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a scientific breakthrough in astrophysics that could deepen our understanding of cosmic evolution and the fate of massive stars. This kind of research expands human knowledge and inspires curiosity about the universe, which is generally seen as positive and hopeful.
articles.personality_title: Ghost particles may quietly shape the fate of collapsing stars
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Neutrinos are tiny, almost invisible particles that hardly interact with anything. Though elusive, they play a surprising role in the life cycle of massive stars—those much bigger than our sun. Scientists have long wondered how neutrinos behave during a star’s dramatic collapse.

**What happened**
New research shows that when massive stars collapse, they create natural “neutrino colliders.” These are environments where neutrinos can bump into each other far more often than in any Earth-based experiment. This discovery allows scientists to study neutrino interactions in ways never before possible.

**Impact**
If neutrinos interact through hidden forces we haven’t yet discovered, they could determine whether a collapsing star becomes a black hole or a neutron star. This insight could change how we understand the evolution of stars and the creation of black holes in the universe.

**What's next step**
Researchers will continue to study these natural neutrino collisions in collapsing stars, looking for signs of new forces or behaviors. This could unlock more secrets about the universe’s most mysterious particles and how they influence cosmic events.

**One-sentence takeaway**
This exciting research reveals that ghostly neutrinos might secretly decide if a massive star ends as a black hole or a neutron star, opening new doors in our understanding of the cosmos.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les particules fantômes pourraient discrètement décider du destin des étoiles en effondrement
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les neutrinos sont des particules minuscules et presque invisibles qui interagissent très peu avec la matière. Bien qu’insaisissables, ils jouent un rôle surprenant dans le cycle de vie des étoiles massives, bien plus grandes que notre soleil. Les scientifiques se demandent depuis longtemps comment les neutrinos se comportent lors de l’effondrement dramatique d’une étoile.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
De nouvelles recherches montrent que lorsque les étoiles massives s’effondrent, elles créent des « collisionneurs naturels de neutrinos ». Ce sont des environnements où les neutrinos peuvent se heurter bien plus souvent que dans n’importe quelle expérience réalisée sur Terre. Cette découverte permet aux scientifiques d’étudier les interactions des neutrinos d’une manière jamais possible auparavant.

**Impact**
Si les neutrinos interagissent via des forces cachées encore inconnues, ils pourraient déterminer si une étoile en effondrement devient un trou noir ou une étoile à neutrons. Cette découverte pourrait changer notre compréhension de l’évolution des étoiles et de la formation des trous noirs dans l’univers.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier ces collisions naturelles de neutrinos dans les étoiles en effondrement, à la recherche de signes de nouvelles forces ou comportements. Cela pourrait révéler davantage de secrets sur les particules les plus mystérieuses de l’univers et leur influence sur les événements cosmiques.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Cette recherche passionnante montre que les neutrinos fantômes pourraient secrètement décider si une étoile massive finit en trou noir ou en étoile à neutrons, ouvrant de nouvelles perspectives dans notre compréhension du cosmos.
articles.personality_title_es: Las partículas fantasma podrían decidir en secreto el destino de las estrellas colapsantes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los neutrinos son partículas diminutas y casi invisibles que apenas interactúan con la materia. Aunque escurridizos, juegan un papel sorprendente en el ciclo de vida de estrellas masivas, mucho más grandes que nuestro sol. Los científicos han preguntado durante mucho tiempo cómo se comportan los neutrinos durante el colapso dramático de una estrella.

**Qué pasó**
Nuevas investigaciones muestran que cuando las estrellas masivas colapsan, crean «colisionadores naturales de neutrinos». Estos son ambientes donde los neutrinos pueden chocar entre sí mucho más seguido que en cualquier experimento en la Tierra. Este descubrimiento permite a los científicos estudiar las interacciones de neutrinos de formas nunca antes posibles.

**Impacto**
Si los neutrinos interactúan a través de fuerzas ocultas aún no descubiertas, podrían determinar si una estrella colapsante se convierte en un agujero negro o en una estrella de neutrones. Esta visión podría cambiar nuestra comprensión de la evolución de las estrellas y la creación de agujeros negros en el universo.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores seguirán estudiando estas colisiones naturales de neutrinos en estrellas colapsantes, buscando señales de nuevas fuerzas o comportamientos. Esto podría desbloquear más secretos sobre las partículas más misteriosas del universo y cómo influyen en los eventos cósmicos.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Esta emocionante investigación revela que los neutrinos fantasma podrían decidir en secreto si una estrella masiva termina como agujero negro o estrella de neutrones, abriendo nuevas puertas en nuestra comprensión del cosmos.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a massive, glowing star collapsing inward, surrounded by swirling, translucent orbs in three distinct colors representing the three neutrino flavors—electron, muon, and tau—interacting and colliding within the star’s core, with subtle streams of light illustrating energy flow and transformation, all rendered in soft, natural hues against a cosmic backdrop.
